rsbNotes.title: Luke 7:37–38
rsbNotes.text: 7:37, 38 At a dinner like this the house would be open and people could come in and watch. A sinful woman (perhaps a prostitute) would not have been welcome; it took courage for her to come. Guests at dinner reclined on couches. Leaning on the left side, they took the food with their right hands.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 7:37
rsbNotes.text: 7:37 alabaster. A translucent stone used to make containers for costly perfumes.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 7:38
rsbNotes.text: 7:38 weeping. The woman’s tears and her anointing of Jesus’ feet demonstrated penitence and humility.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 7:39
rsbNotes.text: 7:39 this man . . . would have known. A Pharisee would have no contact with sinful people, and was sure that no prophet would have such contact either. As Jesus did not dismiss the woman, Simon thought that He either did not know that she was sinful or did not care. In either case, in Simon’s view Jesus could not be a prophet.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 7:44–46
rsbNotes.text: 7:44–46 Simon had omitted the courtesies normally given to guests. But the woman made up for this.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 7:47
rsbNotes.text: 7:47 for. The woman was forgiven because of faith (v. 50). Her love showed that she understood what God’s forgiveness meant for her.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 7:48–50
rsbNotes.text: 7:48–50 Again Jesus authoritatively declares sins to be forgiven, an act that arouses comment (cf. 5:20, 21). But His concern is for the woman.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 8:2
rsbNotes.text:
8:2 Rabbis refused to teach women, so Jesus’ acceptance of them into His group of followers was unusual.

Magdalene. From the town of Magdala.

rsbNotes.title: Luke 8:3
rsbNotes.text: 8:3 out of their means. This provides a glimpse of the way Jesus and His band were supported throughout His ministry.
